content.title: Central Venous Stenosis in Dialysis Patients
content.description: Stenosis or occlusion of the subclavian, brachiocephalic, or superior vena cava veins, usually from prior central venous catheter placement, causing arm swelling and access dysfunction.
content.definition: Central venous stenosis (CVS) is narrowing of the central veins (subclavian, brachiocephalic, or SVC) that impairs venous outflow from dialysis access, causing arm edema, access dysfunction, and potentially access failure. Most commonly results from prior central venous catheter placement.

etiology: Prior central venous catheter (most common cause)

clinical_pearls: Subclavian catheters cause stenosis in 40-50% - avoid in CKD patients
Internal jugular is preferred dialysis catheter site
Prominent chest wall collaterals = central stenosis until proven otherwise
Prevention: Avoid subclavian puncture in dialysis patients
Covered stents have better patency than bare metal for central stenosis
